Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: BiSciCol Tracker: Towards a tagging and tracking infrastructure for biodiversity science collections
Award.AbstractNarration:
Scientific specimens, typically found in museum collections, serve as the anchor for an expanding array of information that grows and changes over time. This information, about specimens and the species that the specimens represent, is often scattered geographically across institutions and across independent computer systems, making it difficult to access or synthesize. The goal of this project is to develop a two-way system of linking and tracking scientific specimens and specimen-related data across biological collections, and to make this system widely available to the scientific community and the public. This system would employ globally unique identifiers, or GUIDs, to tag and update information associated with specimens, allowing communication between end users and collections. This project will improve data quality and quantity for non-scientists and scientists, and will actively engage use communities through training workshops, summer student internships, and community BioBlitz enhancements.

The ability to integrate specimen data and associated information across biological collections will enable critical studies related to systematics, biogeography, and changing species distributions. These in turn have implications for climate change, changing land use, and other questions key to understanding the past, placing changes in an historical context, and predicting the future of species and environments.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Natural history collections provide irreplaceable legacy information about our biosphere in an era of rapid change. At the heart of these collections are biological materials (biomaterials) that have been collected in nature, and brought into museums for perpetuity. Specimens and associated data collected in the field and during downstream accessioning and curatorial processes continue to provide value long after they are first accessioned. For example, specimens can be subsampled providing tissues for molecular analyses. New data, such as DNA sequences, images, and morphological measurements, can be generated many years after the specimen was deposited. The BiSciCol Project seeks to advance knowledge in biological research by ensuring that all the digital content related to biological samples (biosamples) remains connected. The project addresses a growing challenge as biological collections are increasingly digitized, specimens are analyzed using new technologies, biomaterials are exchanged among laboratories worldwide, and data are mobilized globally. As these positive trends continue, it is vital that biomaterials and associated digital resources are made available to support initial use and subsequent re-use. As importantly, downstream data products should easily and directly point back to the original specimen from which they were derived, including information on the time/place of sampling, relevant environmental conditions, and terms of use under which access to the biodiversity was initially granted.

The BiSciCol project is a multi-institutional collaboration developed to tackle the challenge of “tagging and tracking” biological specimens and their many derivatives. It aims for a solution similar to the way that packages shipped via the US mail system have tracking numbers. BiSciCol products range across a broad space including: (1) a rational system for uniquely identifying biomaterials and associated data developed in collaboration with the California Digital Library (CDL). (2) Software called “The Triplifer” and “The Triplifer Simplifier” that takes input biodiversity data in any format, typically in spreadsheets, text files and databases, and creates ready-made outputs in proper formats (RDF, or resource description framework) useful for more effectively linking data together. (3) With the Smithsonian, the project implemented the BiSciCol/CDL identifier solution in enhanced and integrated Field Information Management and Laboratory Information Management Systems. (4) The BiSciCol team contributed significantly to the development of the Biological Collections Ontology, which provides a conceptual framework of biodiversity vocabularies that enable more intuitive interfaces for the discovery of biodiversity data and knowledge.  

Physical biosamples are becoming more significant resources for society given the growing accessibility of advanced imaging and molecular technologies, especially genomics. It is increasingly possible to unpack vast amounts of data from any sample of biological material; a trend that is set to accelerate. The suite of solutions BiSciCol has produced addresses the limited manner in which biological collections data propagate out from the originally collected biosamples. Providing a tailored tracking solution leveraging generic internet technologies, BiSciCol helps connect biomaterials and associated digital data. It enables data driven discovery and will have a broad impact for any application that involves sampling and subsequent analysis of physical biosamples.
